comment_data.body:
Upon closer inspection of the source code, it seems like the label might be used as a backup already? In this case, I'm not sure that I've properly identified the root cause, but my minimal repro config should still suffice for debugging

```
local function apply_defaults(item, defaults)
  if not defaults then
    return
  end

  item.insertTextFormat = item.insertTextFormat or defaults.insertTextFormat
  item.insertTextMode = item.insertTextMode or defaults.insertTextMode
  item.data = item.data or defaults.data
  if defaults.editRange then
    local textEdit = item.textEdit or {}
    item.textEdit = textEdit
    textEdit.newText = textEdit.newText or item.textEditText or item.insertText or item.label
    if defaults.editRange.start then
      textEdit.range = textEdit.range or defaults.editRange
    elseif defaults.editRange.insert then
      textEdit.insert = defaults.editRange.insert
      textEdit.replace = defaults.editRange.replace
    end
  end
end
```

Please test the latest development version. The [Releases](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases/tag/nightly) page has pre-built archives for Linux/Windows/macOS. Check `:version` to confirm the version.

> I'm unsure if the LSP specification indicates any fallback field for the client, but I would assume "label" is some sort of default fallback.

we do what the LSP spec says

@justinmk I just built from source the latest version, and upon some debugging it seems as though the "defaults" 
which get passed to this function
```
local function apply_defaults(item, defaults)
  if not defaults then
    return
  end

  item.insertTextFormat = item.insertTextFormat or defaults.insertTextFormat
  item.insertTextMode = item.insertTextMode or defaults.insertTextMode
  item.data = item.data or defaults.data
  if defaults.editRange then
    local textEdit = item.textEdit or {}
    item.textEdit = textEdit
    textEdit.newText = textEdit.newText or item.textEditText or item.insertText or item.label
    if defaults.editRange.start then
      textEdit.range = textEdit.range or defaults.editRange
    elseif defaults.editRange.insert then
      textEdit.insert = defaults.editRange.insert
      textEdit.replace = defaults.editRange.replace
    end
  end
end
```
are nil. It seems as though then the function returns early, which might be causing no completion results to be populated. Can you give more insight as to what these "defaults" are, and where they come from?
The issue still remains after building the source code, if that was unclear
For curiosity I tried simulated response (without textEdit) in the init file from https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/36337#issuecomment-3450727044 and still get completion result via omnifunc.

@przepompownia I do get omnifunc completion in most cases, its only specifically in situations after builtin types where I have gone past the "." separator, as described in the problem. Did you attempt to replicate this? Especially with typescript-language-server? It seems that file linked deals with the PHP language server. Additionally it is most likely because the defaults are populated, which is the main thing I'm confused about with typescript language server
@Jack-Gitter  I can reproduce your example - only the title sounds too general which may be misleading.

@przepompownia This adjustment now gets the completions properly. I still don't understand what the "defaults" are, but it seems like when defaults for the language server are nil along with no "textEdit" field given from the language server, the completions do not work.  I'm going to try to step through the code to figure out where the defaults are, but in the mean time this generated code fixes the problem

 (WARNING, AI GENERATED CODE AND SHOULD NOT BE USED)    
 
```
local function apply_defaults(item, defaults) 
  defaults = defaults or {} -- fallback to empty table 

  -- Merge basic fields from defaults if missing
  item.insertTextFormat = item.insertTextFormat or defaults.insertTextFormat
  item.insertTextMode = item.insertTextMode or defaults.insertTextMode
  item.data = item.data or defaults.data

  -- Ensure textEdit table exists
  local textEdit = item.textEdit or {}
  item.textEdit = textEdit

  -- Fill newText from item fields or label
  textEdit.newText = textEdit.newText or item.textEditText or item.insertText or item.label or ""

  -- Fill range if defaults.editRange exists
  if defaults.editRange then
    if defaults.editRange.start then
      textEdit.range = textEdit.range or defaults.editRange
    elseif defaults.editRange.insert then
      textEdit.insert = textEdit.insert or defaults.editRange.insert
      textEdit.replace = textEdit.replace or defaults.editRange.replace
    end
  end

  -- Fallback range if still missing (insert at cursor)
  if not textEdit.range and not (textEdit.insert and textEdit.replace) then
    local row, col = unpack(vim.api.nvim_win_get_cursor(0))
    textEdit.range = {
      start = { line = row - 1, character = col }, 
      ["end"] = { line = row - 1, character = col },
    }
  end 
end
```
@przepompownia Thanks for the feedback. I have added to the title, although I'm not 100% sure if is it the root cause of the problem

@justinmk I'm not particularly sure if this solution is robust enough. I'll happily add a PR once I can make sure I know the root-cause, and am able to logically verify the solution. I probably won't get around to it right now though, not for a couple of days maybe
I'm also happy if others who are more knowledgable about LSP and the specific implementation can chime in here

Additional note after looking into that logic: add
```lua
    {
      filterText = '[Symbol2]',
      kind = 6,
      label = 'Symbol2',
      textEdit = {newText = '[Symbol]', range = {['end'] = {character = 2, line = 1}, start = {character = 2, line = 1}}},
    },
```
(different start column) to discard computing based on textEdit in favor of the `isk` based prefix.

Assuming the response is mismatching I doubt there is anything we can do on the Nvim side. 

@MariaSolOs what do you think about this case?

@przepompownia I agree with you. It sounds like the server is returning inconsistent completion items.

@Jack-Gitter have you tried using https://github.com/microsoft/typescript-go? Given how it is the official LSP for TypeScript (still in development tho) if the bug still happens with it then I would feel more confident about this being a Neovim bug.
fwiw, i can repro this with `<c-x><c-o>` after `x.fi` as described (with `typescript-language-server`).

> fwiw, i can repro this with `<c-x><c-o>` after `x.fi` as described.

I can't repro this with `tsgo`.

title: LSP: vim.lsp.omnifunc() does not populate completion menu when LSP "textDocument/completion" response does not include "textEdit" field (and others?) and defaults are nil
